title: Thursday, 3rd January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Morning.

Blackbag99 morning
Tony Scott morning
Manxish Hello everyone
BE11:06am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's incremental addition to the avalanche of comment on a bloody single-product toy maker.

chopper bear gbp puke
BE11:06am

Apple's down 7.7 per cent live.

VV75 morning
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Post its shock warning overnight that everyone predicted.

Blackbag99 I doubt there are many shocked on RTR either
BE11:08am

And we'll all have time to sound off about peak smartphone and Chinese consumer spending and all that junk.

Blank canvas greetings
A. M. morning.
nichoman good morning
BE11:09am

So give me a moment here for my theory.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

1. China's not like anywhere else.

BE11:09am

Because of WeChat.

A. M. so, once upon a time, a shiny apple i-thingy was an object of conspicuous consumption. What has replaced it?
BE11:10am

And WeChat's platform agnostic. The barriers to moving from iPhone to whatever thing the Chinese government is covertly funding are much lower to the Chinese consumer.

TheThunderer The Canada Goose jacket.
11:10 am
BE11:11am

In near enough every other market, iMessage forms a network effect that's a barrier to moving away from Apple. The company is holding your friends and family to ransom, kinda.

Curious weChat offers more than just chat though, more of a broad service
rw42 I'm currently weighing up the likelihood of bricking my S6 by replacing it's battery versus the cost of a new phone..
BE11:12am

That's not true in China, because WeChat, so while China's a busted flush the same picture probably won't repeat to the same severity elsewhere.

VV75 really? I only accidentally use IM, whatsapp all the way usually.
BE11:12am

That's my theory. It's pretty damn simple, but there it is.

11:12 am
IK11:12am

Good theory bryce.

Irish HF guy @VV75 wechat is what's app in China. What's app not allowed, as with FB, Google etc
IK11:13am

Small flyby...

Excel Developer Bryce has a helper! Hello Izzy.
Tom Dalgleish how does wechat obviate the hardware?
BE11:13am

Oh, hello Iz. It's been a while since this was a dialogue.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Your thoughts?

VV75 @Irish, yes but I was referring to BE's talk of us westerners only using IM
Irish HF guy Welcome back Izzy !
IK11:13am

On Apple? I'm afraid I am totally unaware of anything these days. Working hard to improve this. All I know is that there is great demand for my iPhone6s from my 11 month old.

IK11:13am

She likes to bang it on the table

11:13 am
IK11:14am

But I sense she is also brand agnostic

Irish HF guy @Tom, it works on any phone as long as you have enough memory. Agnostic to Iphone. Lets remember, Apple still did $84bn in sales.
IK11:14am

I was trying to figure out if she qualifies as Gen Z? And whether her future purchasing habits have already been assessed by some banking analyst?

IK11:15am

But yes, by and large, I'm still catching up on things. So have no current insight on much at all.

Manxish *anecdotal evidence klaxon* switched from an iPhone to a Nexus a while back, didn't really miss iMessage at all. I find most people use what's app or fb messenger as default now
Tom Dalgleish @Irish, I use wechat. Just another app really but not an operating system
11:15 am
IK11:15am

What i will say is that I've come back to a team that is half here... Tom and Jamie are apparently on their way to Atlanta.

FATDAZ I have touched on this before but the big problem for AAPl in emerging markets is the cost of the hardware which is not sufficiently adjusted to reflect lower incomes Minimum wage in China is Yuan 2240 per month but Apple darent discount Asian phones sales for fear of undermining price points in developed economies
IK11:16am

Some high brow FT Alphaville shmoozing event with economists organised by Brendan.

BE11:16am

Thumbs up

11:16 am
IK11:16am

Unfortunately I have no details. I think it's happening at the weekend. Bryce do you have any other info?

WeChat has various related products etc to monitise the app offering

Anyway, if the yanks got to organise their own thing... I think it's only fair we should organise some sort of London equivalent meetup.. an op for you guys to update me on everything I've missed Teeth smile

undefined
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Anyway, back to Apple for the usual sellside bumf.

BE11:20am

Oppenheimer:

BE11:20am

We believe the press release and guidance miss raises more questions than answers. 1) What is wrong in China? 2) Where does the iPhone go from here? 3) Is it clear yet, that Apple has a gross margin problem? The calming affect and what drives earnings growth in our model is capital returns. We remain solidly on the sideline as we continue to believe investors are not pricing in longer-term risks. One caveat for the bull thesis: March 2016 quarter was the last miss....on emerging market weakness.

Excel Developer Is Brendan Cardiff Garcia's replacement, will there be FOMC Markets Live again?
11:20 am
BE11:21am

"raises more questions than it answers" and "solidly on the sidelines" ... super.

BE11:21am

We don't think Apple is the only one with growth problems. We believe it's industry wide: higher prices, combined with fewer new features that provide real utility, are the biggest culprit. For Apple, we do worry this leads to margin degradation and a focus on what's the next cycle driver (5G, AR, healthcare?).

Izabella Kaminska @excel - yes Brendan is the new FT Alphaville americas editor. I'm sure we can persuade him and Colby to run an FOMC ML
BE11:21am

What's next? We believe with slowing smartphone revenue, possibly degrading ASPs, investors will start to worry about gross margins. For example, iPhone revenue levels are similar to December 2015. Then, service and wearable sales were half of what they are today, yet gross margins are lower by over 200 bps. Additionally, take rates, innovations, and M&A may become dominant story line.

rw42 Think pretty much everyone i know uses whatsapp these days, doubt there's much lockin for iMessage any more
Excel Developer @IK: cool, cheers
11:21 am
BE11:22am

In the meantime of everyone playing Monday morning quarterback (us included)—we suspect Apple will continue to chug along—albeit with little to no growth. However, with a cash neutral policy, that's a lot of share buybacks and dividends over the coming years.

BE11:22am

(I don'k know what a Monday morning quarterback is.)

Excel Developer @BE: armchiar general
A. M. @rw42: whatsapp has the unfortunate side-effect of sharing stuff with FB, doesn't it?
Mr Gekko @BE surely the same is true of whatsapp outside of China ? there are no real barriers only slaves to certain brands
BE11:23am

(A.M.: oddly, no.)

Blackbag99 The margin thing could take a long time to evolve with Apple. When you have hit suppliers with volume discounts, what happens when you can't produce volumes. Slow burn hard crunch a bit like Tesco probably.
Curious Apple have heaps of cash, so assume a couple of buy backs, then all they need is the next iPhone, which they can afford to develop
11:23 am
BE11:23am

(@RW42: that's not even slightly true among the non-tech-literate, who are the majority.)

Patri @A.M. I was thinkis it is slightly opposite with sharing info

BE11:24am

And Citi.

Rick Chasey Customer awareness of batteries & phones reaching a point where the differences between new models in terms of performance is small enough that they'll save money and just replace the battery, no?
BE11:24am

Apple cited the majority of its sales miss from China which last quarter represented 18% of the company’s total sales which we estimate is now closer to 10-12%. While our financial model was below consensus we again lower our model and target price to $170 from $200 based on this news. In this report we show our scenario analysis which can help answer How Low Can Apple Stock Go? We do not expect much positive news until after earnings slated for late January and even then the focus will be how low can sales go (-5% y/y in December and we project –2% y/y in March) and while bulls will cite stock buyback and low valuation trading at 11x F12M PE we don’t expect any rally in the shares in the near term until consensus get materially reset lower and trade wars get resolved.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

What if China Sales Went to Zero? China represented 18% of total sales for
Apple last quarter. We estimate if China sales went to zero that would reduce iPhone units by -44m and approximately ~$20-$30 per share in Apple stock price. While we don’t expect zero sales to occur we believe investors will value this framework and the scenario analysis in this report.

FATDAZ re Apple did anyone see the story about Netflix circumventing the APP store and Apple fees worth abouT US$256 mln per annum to AAPL so small potatoes but shows other tech firms / service providers are resistant to their ecosphere
Irish HF guy @Rick, or insert a micro SD card if Android and use as internal storage formatting the card and enhancing the utility of the phone for another year or so at a low SD card cost 13euro for 32mb retail

I can't immediately find that framework so have the bull-bear instead.

This current issue for the iPhone is a factor in waning consumer appetite, lower volumes, resistance to higher pricing, slowing innovation, and saturation. Now the Apple suppliers have already significantly derated on valuation of course, as this chart below depicts. And some have, of course, recently guided lower. But, you can expect that many will likely warn again:

Bluesky21 Tim Cook’s letter also has a paragraph about issues in developed markets - upgrade cycle slowing, people need new phones less because of battery replacements, etc.
Curious wireless headphones are very popular these days
A. M. @Rw42: indeed, I read something in ElReg on FB's wish to mess about with the encryption.
BE11:28am

BE11:29am

One fallout from this shift that does stand out though is Dialog Semi. With a successful PMIC deal with Apple that includes an upfront payment of $600M from Apple, an underwriting of Apple business (30-35% CAGR for non-mobile PMIC business) , a net cash balance of $800M post deal and non-mobile business growth to grow at 10-15% CAGRR for 2018-2022 the company could be the baby that has been thrown out with the bathwater.

(In the semiconductor complex we currently have nine sell rated stocks and zero buys. These Sells are: Infineon, Taiyo Yuden, Himax, Nissha, Melexis, VAT Group, Microchip, Qualcomm, and Renesas. And the China issue is likely not exclusive to Apple alone – we see risks to Xiaomi (Sell rated) being squeezed between One Plus and Huawei.)

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Caz.

A. M. here: https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/03/14/whatsapp_facebook_user_info/
BE11:29am

Apple’s guidance cut of $7bn (at the midpoint) implies roughly 9m unit cut (assuming $800 ASP). Based on Apple’s indication of 19% YoY growth in non-iPhone businesses in Dec qtr, the implied iPhone revenue decline is ~15% YoY. With the onset of a seasonally slow 1H19, we believe that the YoY comps are likely to remain tough for the supply chain over the next couple of quarters. Within our coverage universe, the companies impacted include ams, Dialog, and STMicroelectronics. Although ams has already issued a profit warning in November, we believe that the extent of Apple weakness could prompt further estimate cuts. Further, we believe that STMicroelectronics and Dialog, which have not issued any profit warning yet, will now almost certainly do so or issue very weak March qtr guidance.

BE11:30am

Will also note luxury in passing, since Apple seems to be considered a barometer of Chinese luxury goods spending ....... which is a bit weird.

sprout curious that Apple stores were running a battery replacement promotion in the lead up to Christmas, I wonder if that had an effect. 25 euros for an official replacement stopped Mrs Sprout from upgrading.

The People's Operator plc

("TPO", the "Company" or the "Group")

Notice of Intention to Appoint an Administrator

On 31 December 2018 the Board resolved to file notice of intention to appoint administrators to the Company and the notice was filed on 2 January 2019. Unless circumstances change, and in accordance with statutory requirements, the Board intends to appoint administrators within 10 business days.

The Directors remain in discussions with potentially interested parties with a view to protecting the position of creditors. There can be no guarantee however that such discussions will conclude satisfactorily.

As previously announced, trading in the Company's shares on AIM will be cancelled at 7.00 a.m. on 3 January 2019.

BE11:40am

Let's try Nomura instead.

BE11:41am

These are the two of the most commonly used expressions to characterise the dynamics of FX carry trades. That is, you steadily pick up small returns for months before you lose it all in one day. Today’s collapse in USD/JPY from around 109.5 to an intraday low of 104.9 can be seen in that light. That low essentially reverses the almost 10% spot gains seen since the eerily similar USD/JPY low of 104.7 in April 2018

BE11:42am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Over the past few hours there has been a bounce in USD/JPY to 107.8, suggesting that early year poor liquidity has contributed to the moves. The larger question is whether we have seen the worst for USD/JPY. In our year-ahead dollar piece we argued that USD/JPY will reach 100-105 over 2019, but we didn’t expect the move to happen in the first week. The fundamentals laid out in that piece for a lower USD/JPY still hold though – poor US current account dynamics, US carry being too low for US risks and US growth outperformance fading. So unless the US cycle turns up, we think it’s hard to turn too structurally bullish USD/JPY even at these levels.

News: 4Q19 Next Brand sales to 24 December +1.5% (Bloomberg consensus +0.5%), split Next Retail sales/LFL -9.2%-10.3% (consensus -7.3%-8.3%) and Directory +15.2% (consensus +9.7%).
FY19 guidance update:
- Full price sales +3.2% (from +3.0%)
- PBT £723mn (from £727mn; consensus £728mn, GSe £730mn) reflecting impact of higher online and weaker retail sales vs expectations
- EPS +4.4% yoy (GSe +4.7% yoy)
FY20 guidance introduced:
- Full price sales +1.7% (GSe +2.8%)
- PBT £715mn, -1.1% yoy (consensus £728mn, GSe £730mn)
- EPS +3.6% yoy (GSe +4.8% yoy)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

What does it all mean? Other things equal, this would imply FY19/20 Bloomberg consensus PBT reductions of -0.7%/-1.8% to meet the revised/new guidance of £723mn/£715mn (EPS 435.0p/450.7p, +4.4%/+3.6% yoy).
Valuation: Our 12-month price target of 5,800p is DCF-derived and implies an 11.5x FY20E target EV/EBIT multiple. We are Neutral rated.

red @Excel Developerfwiw fx is all about stops and positioning. mkt was long usdjpy. now its largely flat. so this pair unlikely to exhibit usd weakness relatively
BE11:48am

So .... the story doesn't really change much. Next's still a credit mail order business with legacy real estate that can churn free cashflow into share buybacks.

chad_john price target of +30% odd and only Neutral rated? Hm.
BE11:48am

Citi:

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Next's 4Q trading is slightly better than feared given the wider industry commentary (8wk Brand sales +1.5% vs Citi +0.1%) and FY19 PBT
guidance lowered by only £4m to £723m. FY20e PBT guidance of £715m (Citi £703.4m, cons c.£727m) implies that consensus PBT forecasts are likely to fall c.1.5%. This implies a PBT decline of c-1.5% in FY20E but should be more than offset by the share buyback accretion of c.4.5% (Citi £300m forecast). Given the c.-20% decline in the share price in the last 3 months, this now seems largely reflected in the share price. The lower than expected guidance for FY19E and FY20E is all largely online deleverage related and although we expect a relief rally in the share price today, this structural headwind will likely stop the shares getting carried away.

red @Excel Developerlol no but er i did take advantage of some good conditions a few yrs back.
BE11:49am

They're sellers.

BE11:49am

We have been concerned over the impact of online deleverage as lower Retail profit holds back group profit growth. We set our target price using a 10.5x FY19E PE multiple to give 4300p. This target price equates to a c.10x EV/EBIT multiple and 3.6% dividend yield for the same forecast year.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

In sector terms, does Next doing okay mean very much? Of course not.

BE11:52am

Though if you're playing the secular shift theory, then there may be reasons for optimism. Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:52am

The John Lewis data yesterday suggested that the last two weeks of the year picked up markedly (especially in fashion) and the NEXT chart backs that up (as does the lack of retail sector profit warnings so far this year!). Shoppers’ confidence in the reliability of online deliveries gets greater every year, and thus Christmas gets later and later if the retailer in question can manage its stock effectively for the new normal. We think that the relative winners this Christmas will be those that are genuinely multi-channel, with a genuine proximity to their customers. We aren’t saying that life is rosy for the retail sector at the moment, but the rather indiscriminate sell off of the sector does offer opportunities: we would reiterate what we said in our year’s preview note this morning (“Not the gift we were looking for”) in that investors should look for the quality structural or online growth plays. JD, Joules, boohoo and G4M look safe havens, and more speculatively, ASOS looks interesting.

11:52 am
undefined

BE11:53am

Speaking of Peel Hunt and Asos, here's Peel Hunt on Asos.

BE11:53am

We reinstate our Buy recommendation on ASOS (from Under Review) following December’s shock profit warning and share price fall. We believe ASOS did not react strongly enough to the heavy levels of discounting in the market around Black Friday. Early indications suggest trading levels have picked up into December’s clearance activity and we may well see February’s trading update confirm sales performance is above revised full year guidance of 15% Group revenue growth. As one of the leading global fashion websites, we view the current share price weakness as a rare buying opportunity.

Baidu chief executive Robin Li Yanhong warned that “winter is coming” as China’s economy shifts to a lower gear, while challenging employees at the company he co-founded to step up their game.

While economic restructuring is “as cold and real as winter to every company,” Li said in a letter to staff on the first working day of the year, the “historical transformation of AI is penetrating various industries, unleashing enormous growth potential and room for upgrade.”
